turns.speaker: GLENDA
turns.text: The girl's name was Doreen. That's all I know.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: And you didn't know her last name?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Well, it's Carter. That's my name,  And her father was my brother. And he was murdered last Sunday. Now get up and get dressed.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: We weren't sure where it was taking place, like.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No. Frank was a good bloke.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: It's a bloody funny thing. You know a bloke for six bloody years and all the time he's as calm as gentle Jesus...  ...then he goes and does a thing like that.  It's a bloody funny thing.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Let her go. She'll be OK.  Sorry about that.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Don't worry. She's bound to be upset.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: No. I'll be off now. I should be at work.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Look, look.  Get your suit cleaned.

turns.speaker: EDDIE
turns.text: Frank was a good bloke. It's the least I could have done.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Tell me, Doreen, did the police say anything?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Where you going to live, then?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Nice family, are they? Church-goers and all that?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Good. I'm off tomorrow, so I don't suppose I'll see you again.  There. Go and get your hair done.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: I couldn't believe it when I heard. Carter is suddenly attentive.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: I mean, I was surprised when he didn't turn up for work.  He was always on time.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Did you work with him, Keith?

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Come off it. Frank was... well... straight. He had no worries I know. Hell, we worked together every day for a year. It would have showed.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: It just would. He was always the same.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Since when did he drink whisky?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Keith, if anybody comes in here and asks for me, you let me know. Right?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I'm at the Las Vegas. Behind the dance hall.  Do you know a man called Albert Swift?

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Yeah. He comes in here a bit.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Today? At the races. He always goes.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Went to school with him.  He was leader of our gang. He'll know what's going on in this town.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Heard of a man called Thorpe?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Old Thorpey? Haven't seen him in a long time.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: That's what he was saying about you.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Said he'd heard you were up in town. Wondered if I knew where you was staying. Wanted to look you up. Old time's sake.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: That's nice. What'd you tell him?

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Thorpey. They were waiting for us in the car park.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Ah, Edna, come in. Join the tea set.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Cliff Brumby. Ever been to Westsea?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Ever been into an arcade there and put a penny in the slot machine?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Ten to one, it belonged to Cliff Brumby, and like as not the bloody arcade as well. Right along the coast. Isn't that right, Thorpey?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Did they give you a rough time?

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: No.  You bastard. You knew they'd come back.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No, I didn't,  Does Albert Swift still live over the ferry?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: All right. All right. I want to square things with you first.

turns.speaker: KEITH
turns.text: Stuff it! My girl friend's coming from Liverpool tonight.  Nice surprise, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I'm sorry. Here. This'll pay for a course in karate.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I won't be using the room tonight.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Her husband docks tomorrow, does he?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Very nice.  I'll pay you for tonight as well.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Don't be bloody silly. You're the first since Monday.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I'll bet this one's seen some action.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: What the bloody hell do you think you're at?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Don't come that bloody flannel with me. If you're a traveller, I'm bloody Twiggy.  And who's he?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Inside? Why should I give house- room to your sort?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Up the stairs, Keith. The door on the right.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: And what you going to do?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Make us a nice cup of tea and I'll tell you. I might even let you watch.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Suppose you tell me what the bloody hell's going on. It's my house, you know.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yes, Edna, and I must say you've been great about the ...

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: Stick the soft soap. Let's be having it.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You're lucky. They kill as well.

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: And what about you? Did you kill Brumby?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What am I supposed to do?  I don't know where they've taken him. Do you?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: What's that gun doing in your room? Suppose I phoned the police and told them there's a bloke staying in my hotel who's planning to shoot somebody?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: 'Cos I know you wear purple underwear.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You must be joking. I never eat breakfast,  Did you sleep well?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No. I'm not tired,  Do you eat breakfast?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: What, and get myself beaten up again?

turns.speaker: EDNA
turns.text: And that'll make me feel better?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I don't want to get rough, do I?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I'm going to sit in the car and whistle 'Rule, Britannia'.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: What you doing around here then?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Didn't you know this is my home town?

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: Thanks. So what're you doing? On your holidays?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: It would be. If they were still living.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: A bereavement. A death in the family.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: Well, well. Small world, isn't it?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Very...  So, who you working for these days Eric?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What are you doing? Advertising Martini?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yeah,  Come off it, Eric. Who is it?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I've always ad your welfare at heart, Eric. Besides which, I'm nosy.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: That's not always a healthy way to be...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: And you should know, if I remember rightly.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: So you're doing all right then, Eric. You're making good.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Good prospects for advancement, is there? A pension?  Do you know, I'd almost forgotten what your eyes looked like.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: They're still the same. Piss holes in the snow.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: Still got a sense of humour?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yes, I retained that, Eric.  Do you know a man called Albert Swift, Eric?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You should have told me who you were working for.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Oh, Cyril, eh? So it's all girls together, is it?

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: He's thinking Sid and Gerald won't like it much when they hear you've been sticking your nose in.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: You're finished, Jack. You know that, don't you? I've bloody finished you.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You couldn't win an egg and spoon race, Eric.

turns.speaker: ERIC
turns.text: Still got your sense of humour.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yes, I can see your problem, Mr Kinnear.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Sit down, Jack,  I could weep. I really could. Sometimes I think I'll retire. Just piss off to the Bahamas and let somebody else employ them,  Glenda, get Jack a drink. What is it, Jack?

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Eric told me of your bereavement.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Do you know, I never knew he worked in one of my places!

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No? Funny that. Neither did I.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: If I'd known, I'd have fixed him up with something better.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I have to. Things to see to.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Of course, of course. Well, any time, just drop by.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yeah, I'll do that.  Told you it wouldn't take long, didn't I?

turns.speaker: CON
turns.text: Gerald phoned us in the middle of the night, said he'd heard you've been making a nuisance of yourself.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We've got to take you back to London.

turns.speaker: CON
turns.text: He said it'd be doing him a big favour.

turns.speaker: CON
turns.text: We know why you're all steamed up, and so do Gerald and Sid.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But they have to be diplomatic.

turns.speaker: CON
turns.text: Put it away, Jack. You know you won't use it.

turns.speaker: CON
turns.text: Gerald wants to see him first.

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Bollock naked with his socks still on?

turns.speaker: GERALD
turns.text: Ask Jack. It's his old stamping ground.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Are we here to play cards or talk about the old days?

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Harry! Jack, I don't want to be rude, but these men have brought a lot of money with them. Glenda, you don't offer a man like Jack a drink in those piddling little glasses.  Give him the bloody bottle.  Now, where are we?

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Oh... I think I'll stay as I am.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: That's what you pay to find out. Right, Jack?

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: That, Harry? That's another hundred - twenty-five pounds notes of the realm.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: That's six hundred pounds, Harry. Two hundred to follow you, and I've raised it four hundred.

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: Calling my bluff, are you, Harry?

turns.speaker: KINNEAR
turns.text: How about that, Jack?  Old Harry thought I was having him on.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: All of 'em.  They, hey: it happens to us all.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: Where am I going to work?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You have to cheer up, George, you aren't out yet.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You missed a fucking sale.  Big deal.  A deadbeat Polack.  Big deal. How you going to sell 'em in the first place...?  Your mistake, you shoun'a took the lead.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: To get on the board.  Yeah.  How you goan'a get on the board sell'n a Polack?  And I'll tell you, I'll tell you what else.  You listening? I'll tell you what else: don't ever try to sell an Indian.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: I'd never try to sell an Indian.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You get those names come up, you ever get 'em, "Patel?"

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: Well, I think I had one once.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You had one you'd know it.  Patel. They keep coming up.  I don't know. They like to talk to salesmen.  They're lonely, something.  They like to feel superior, I don't know.  Never bought a fucking thing. You're sitting down "The Rio Rancho this, the blah blah blah," "The Mountain View--" "Oh yes.  My brother told me that..." They got a grapevine.  Fuckin' Indians, George. Not my cup of tea.  Speaking of which I want to tell you something:  I never got a cup of tea with them. You see them in the restaurants.  A supercilious race.  What is this look on their face all the time?  I don't know.  I don't know.  Their broads all look like they just got fucked with a dead cat, I don't know.  I don't know.  I don't like it. Christ...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: The whole fuckin' thing...The pressure's just too great.  You're ab...you're absolu...they're too important.  All of them.  You go in the door.  I..."I got to close this fucker, or I don't eat lunch," "or I don't win the Cadillac..." We fuckin' work too hard.  You work too hard.  We all, I remember when we were at Platt...huh?  Glen Ross Farms... didn't we sell a bunch of that..."

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: They came in and they, you know...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: We're stuck with this fucking shit...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You get a bad month, all of a...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: All of, they got you on this "board..."

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: And it's not right to the customers.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: I know it's not.  I'll tell you, you got, you know, you got...what did I learn as a kid on Western? Don't sell a guy one car.  Sell him five cars over fifteen years.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Goddamn right, that's right.  Guys come on: "Oh, the blah blah blah, I know what I'll do: I'll go in and rob everyone blind and go to Argentina cause nobody ever thought of this before."

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: And so they kill the goose.  I, I, I'll...and a fuckin' man, worked all his life has got to...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: For some fuckin' "Sell ten thousand and you win the steak knives..."

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: ...sales promotion, "You lose, then we fire your..." No.  It's medieval... it's wrong. "Or we're going to fire your ass." It's wrong.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Yes, it is.  And you know who's responsible?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You know who it is.  It's Mitch. And Murray.  'Cause it doesn't have to be this way.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Look at Jerry Graff.  He's clean, he's doing business for himself, he's got his, that list of his with the nurses...see?  You see?  That's thinking.  Why take ten percent?  A ten percent comm...why are we giving the rest away?  What are we giving ninety per...for nothing. For some jerk sit in the office tell you "Get out there and close." "Go win the Cadillac." Graff.  He goes out and buys.  He pays top dollar for the... you see?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's thinking.  Now, he's got the leads, he goes in business for himself.  He's...that's what I... that's thinking! "Who?  Who's got a steady job, a couple bucks nobody's touched, who?"

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: So Graff buys a fucking list of nurses, one grand--if he paid two I'll eat my hat--four, five thousand nurses, and he's going wild...

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: I heard that they were running cold.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You hear a lot of things...He's doing very well.  He's doing very well.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: River Oaks, Brook Farms.  All of that shit.  Somebody told me, you know what he's clearing himself? Fourteen, fifteen grand a week.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's what I'm saying.  Why?  The leads.  He's got the good leads... what are we, we're sitting in the shit here.  Why?  We have to go to them to get them.  Huh.  Ninety percent our sale, we're paying to the office for the leads.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: The leads, the overhead, the telephones, there's lots of things.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: What do you need? A telephone, some broad to say "Good morning," nothing...nothing...

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: No, it's not that simple, Dave...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Yes.  It is.  It is simple, and you know what the hard part is?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Of doing the thing.  The dif...the difference.  Between me and Jerry Graff.  Going to business for yourself.  The hard part is...you know what it is?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: To say "I'm going on my own." 'Cause what you do, George, let me tell you what you do: you find yourself in thrall to someone else. And we enslave ourselves.  To please.  To win some fucking toaster...to...to... and the guy who got there first made up those...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: He made up those rules, and we're working for him.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's the God's truth.  And it gets me depressed.  I swear that it does.  At MY AGE.  To see a goddamn: "Somebody wins the Cadillac this month.  P.S. Two guys get fucked."

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You don't ax your sales force.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You fucking build it!  Men come...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Look look look look, when they build your business, then you can't fucking turn around, enslave them, treat them like children, fuck them up the ass, leave them to fend for themselves... no.  No.  You're absolutely right, and I want to tell you something.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: I want to tell you what somebody should do.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Someone should stand up and strike back.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Something.  To pay them back.  Someone, someone should hurt them. Murray and Mitch.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: How?  Do something to hurt them. Where they live.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's what I'm saying.  We were, if we were that kind of guys, to knock it off, and trash the joint, it looks like robbery, and take the fuckin' leads out of the files...go to Jerry Graff.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: What could somebody get for them?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: What could we get for them?  I don't know.  Buck a throw...buck-a- half a throw...I don't know...Hey, who knows what they're worth, what do they pay for them?  All told...must be, I'd... three bucks a throw...I don't know.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: How many leads have we got?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: The Glengarry...the premium leads...? I'd say we got five thousand.  Five. Five thousand leads.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: And you're saying a fella could take and sell these leads to Jerry Graff.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: How do you know he'd buy them?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Graff?  Because I worked for him.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: No.  What do you mean?  Have I talked to him about this?

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: Yes.  I mean are you actually talking about this, or are we just...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: We're just speaking about it.  As an idea.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: We're not actually talking about it.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: So all this, um, you didn't, actually, you didn't go talk to Graff.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Yes.  I said, "Not actually." The fuck you care, George?  We're just talking...

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: Because, because, you know, it's a crime.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's right.  It's a crime.  It is a crime.  It's also very safe.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: You're going to steal the leads?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: What did he say?  He'd buy them.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: However they are, that's the deal. A buck a throw.  Five thousand dollars.  Split it half and half.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Yes.  Twenty-five hundred apiece.  One night's work, and the job with Graff.  Working the premium leads.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: He would take you on.  Yes.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Yes.  It is, George.  Yes.  It's a big decision.  And it's a big reward.  It's a big reward.  For one night's work.  But it's got to be tonight.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: You have to steal the leads tonight?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: That's right, the guys are moving them downtown.  After the thirtieth. Murray and Mitch.  After the contest.

turns.speaker: AARONOW
turns.text: You're, you're saying so you have to go in there tonight and...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: You have to go in.  You have to get the leads.
